info.game_comments:
2006 Celebrity Jeopardy! game 6.
From Radio City Music Hall in New York City.

jeopardy_round: CAN I BUY YOU A DRINK?

(1, 1).clue: The status of the 2,270-sq.-mi. area on this shore of the Jordan is contested by Palestinians & Israelis

(2, 1).clue: Keith Carradine's role as Wild Bill Hickok on this series ended when Jack McCall killed Hickok

(3, 1).clue: Want to marry this ex-wife of Burton, Todd, Hilton & Fisher?  Fuhgettaboudit!  She says she's staying single

(4, 1).clue: North Little Rock is the sixth-largest city in this state

(5, 1).clue: Cuba Libre is just a fancy name for plain old rum, a hint of lime & this

(6, 1).clue: The Vezina Trophy is for hockey's best one of these

(1, 2).clue: Deganya in the Jordan Valley is this type of Israeli collective settlement, the country's oldest

(2, 2).clue: This veteran Pulitzer-winning film critic trades reviews with Richard Roeper

(3, 2).clue: Trying to locate this country just to the east of the old Berlin Wall on a map?  Fuhgettaboudit!  It's gone

(4, 2).clue: "I love" this city, America's biggest metropolis--doesn't everyone?

(5, 2).clue: It's a little early in the day--maybe time for this champagne & orange juice cocktail

(6, 2).clue: It's the type of dog seen here

(1, 3).clue: East of the Jordan, the Ghor Canal has made orange groves spring up by doing this to once-barren land

(2, 3).clue: In one episode of this comedienne's Bravo Channel show "My Life on the D-List", she auctioned off a stay in her home

(3, 3).clue: Hoping to get on the Olympic team for this event where 2 sides pull on a rope?  Fuhgettaboudit!  Last held in 1920

(4, 3).clue: This small U.S. state is only about half the size of Delaware

(5, 3).clue: A Scotch Manhattan, with scotch & sweet vermouth, usually goes by the name of this Scottish outlaw

(6, 3).clue: This type of animal torments Bill Murray in "Caddyshack"

(2, 4).clue: This cable channel's "Meerkat Manor" has been billed as "'All My Children' meets 'Wild Kingdom'"

(3, 4).clue: Want to join this religion so you can have more than one spouse?  Fuhgettaboudit!  Canceled the practice in 1890

(4, 4).clue: Any Texan can tell you that this city is "Big D"

(5, 4).clue: You might enjoy this drink, classically made with equal parts of orange juice & peach schnapps

(6, 4).clue: This large African animal (which did not torment Bill Murray in "Caddyshack") can make about 20 different sounds

(2, 5).clue: In June 2006 this movie channel premiered its first made-for-TV movie, "Broken Trail", starring Robert Duvall

(3, 5).clue: Hungry for food using this flavor enhancer abbreviated MSG?  Fuhgettaboudit!  Many places have stopped using it

(5, 5).clue: How about a martini or this identical cocktail garnished with an onion instead of an olive

(6, 5).clue: This 4-letter word means to spur, push or impel

(1, 1).clue: A 19th c. duchess who felt faint in the afternoon began the British custom of serving tiny little cakes with this beverage

(2, 1).clue: The Ft. Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel called this Vegas diva a "soprano geyser"; somehow, "My Heart Will Go On"

(3, 1).clue: As this title superhero, Tobey Maguire spun his web across New York

(4, 1).clue: The first Grammy for Best Rap Performance went to DJ Jazzy Jeff & this "Fresh Prince"

(5, 1).clue: These masses of tissue in the throat, below the adenoids, fight infection but have to go if they become infected

(1, 2).clue: Re-enactors still buy hardtack crackers from the G.H. Bent Co. of Mass., which supplied them for this 1860s war

(2, 2).clue: "The Hills Are Alive" with the sound of this Oscar-winning soprano's voice, whether she's Victor or Victoria

(3, 2).clue: On a Manhattan morning, Audrey Hepburn admires the gems in a shop window while eating a roll in this film's opening

(4, 2).clue: Betty Smith wrote about young Francie Nolan in her novel "A Tree Grows in" this New York City borough

(5, 2).clue: Though there is elbow-replacement surgery, the knees & this higher joint are the ones replaced most often

(1, 3).clue: This Roman emperor served his guests snow mixed with honey (& probably bored them with his fiddle-playing)

(2, 3).clue: Of her 1994 Xmas CD, USA Today said, this "Vision Of Love" diva had "a soprano that could unhinge St. Peter's gate"

(3, 3).clue: A classic Christmas movie is called "Miracle on" this Manhattan street

(4, 3).clue: Winston Smith is a writer of Newspeak for the Ministry of Truth in this George Orwell novel

(5, 3).clue: Removal of the gallbladder is the usual treatment for concretions better known as these

(1, 4).clue: It's said that this French emperor's chef created Chicken Marengo for him right on the battlefield

(2, 4).clue: Maria Jeritza must have been lovely to have Strauss write the role of this beauty of Troy for her--see for yourself

(3, 4).clue: This writer/director's New York-set films include "Manhattan" & "Manhattan Murder Mystery"

(4, 4).clue: A New York City Fire Department fireboat is named for this 1928 pres. candidate known as the "Happy Warrior"

(5, 4).clue: It's a general term for surgery that requires an incision right into your ticker

(1, 5).clue: Mme. Pompadour loved to top filet of sole with these fancy fungi

(2, 5).clue: In the 1940s Rise Stevens owned the role of this Spanish Gypsy at the Met & sang it in the film "Going My Way"

(3, 5).clue: Who ya gonna call when spirits haunt the Big Apple?  The title group of this 1984 comedy, of course

(4, 5).clue: Economist Adam Smith is best known for "An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of" this

(5, 5).clue: Gastric bypass isn't for the chunky or the just overweight, but for BMI over 35, classed as being this

(0, 0).clue: Producer David Selznick was fined $5,000 by censors for using this word in a 1939 film
